Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Increasing American Participation and Integrating the 'omics' in the Second International Conference on Oxidative Stress in Aquatic Ecosystems. Nov 11-14, 2015; La Paz, MX
Award.AbstractNarration:
Oxidative stress results from the imbalance between free radical production and cellular detoxification and repair. At large interdisciplinary conferences, presentations addressing oxidative stress tend to be scattered throughout the program, often at concurrent sessions. Those conferences that focus on oxidative stress do so almost exclusively within the contexts of medicine or toxicology. Following a successful First International Conference on Oxidative Stress in Aquatic Habitats in 2012; this award will support portions of the Second International Conference on Oxidative Stress in Aquatic Habitats. Funds will support symposium speakers who integrate the 'omics' into their research programs and will support the conference attendance of U.S. students, postdoctoral associates, and early career scientists.

The conference structure will include three types of working group sessions that will create synergy across disciplines and nationalities and enhance the development of collaborations. The conference design creates a unique opportunity to contribute to the interdisciplinary and global workforce needed for the Genomes - Phenomes Grand Challenge. Summative assessments will provide valuable information about what components of the conference design were most effective at facilitating collaborations and bridging disciplines and nationalities. Support from this award will enable participation by students, postdoctoral associates and early career scientists who self-identify into one or more category of underrepresented status. This will help increase the diversity of the STEM workforce that participates in international collaborations and that is engaged in studying the genome - phenome continuum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, we requested funding to support the travel of graduate students, postdoctoral associates, and faculty from U.S. institutions to the Second International Conference on Oxidative Stress in Aquatic Ecosystems. The conference was held November 11-14,2015 in La Paz, Baja California Sur (MX). At the first conference, which was held in 2012, only four of the conference attendees (7% of the conference attendees) were from the U.S., two of whom were members of the organizing committee. This project facilitated the participation of U.S. scientists in a conference that focused on a global problem: the environmental factors that can induce oxidative stress in aquatic organisms. At the 2015 conference there were 14 participants from the U.S. (21% of the conference attendees). The three-day conference was attended by 67 participants, representing 14 countries.

The objectives of this project were to:

Increase the participation of scientists from U.S. institutions at the Second International Conference on Oxidative Stress in Aquatic Ecosystems.

Increase the conference attendance of U.S. students, postdoctoral associates and young investigators who are from traditionally underrepresented groups in the STEM disciplines.

Catalyze the addition of the ‘omics’ into the conference with the goal of facilitating integration of the ‘omics’ into the research programs of conference attendees.

Facilitate the creation of new collaborations, particularly those that involve grant-sponsored participants, that are international and/or that are interdisciplinary and address multiple points along the genome – phenome continuum.

Of the 14 attendees who were from U.S. institutions, eleven received complete financial support. Of these, four are faculty members, three are postdoctoral associates, two are Ph.D. students and two are M.S. students. Demographic information was collected from the seven students/postdoctoral associates: four are women, two identify as first-generation college students, and three identify as belonging to an ethnic minority group.  The three participants who received partial support are faculty members. All 14 U.S. participants gave either oral or poster presentations.

There were two components of the intellectual merit of this project. First, many of the attendees explore oxidative stress by using tools from biochemistry and cellular physiology or by measuring traits like growth and fecundity. To facilitate the incorportion of the ‘omics’ with these traditional approaches, six U.S. participants presented ‘omics’ data. Only one of the other 53 conference attendees presented ‘omics’ data. Second, to facilitate the development of collaborations, this project supported the generation of three working group sessions. In the first session, all conference participants were involved in two (small-)group discussions; participants were grouped on the basis of their research interests. In the second session, an NSF Program Director gave a video conference in which international funding opportunities at NSF were discussed. In the final session, all attendees participated in a brainstorming session about strategies to address the design and interpretation of experiments that involve multiple environmental stressors.

The broader impacts of this project were to increase the participation of young scientists, particularly those from underrepresented groups, in an international conference. The graduate students and postdoctoral associates received formal and informal mentoring about conference attendance and best practices for searching for postdoctoral/faculty positions.
